comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: You can see Fort Macquarie in this shot.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think this ship is the RMS MOLDAVIA (1) P&O (1903), which was on her maiden voyage to Australia in January 1904. She moored off Neutral Bay from 22-27 January, and moved to Circular Quay (the P&O wharf as seen here) on 27 January until 6 February. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RMS_Moldavia www.clydesite.co.uk/clydebuilt/viewship.asp?id=15332 Used as the Anniversary Day Regatta Flagship 26/1/1904 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14595652 Sunk by a German U-boat in 1918 when carrying US troops off Beachy Head UK - www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?562 So she was at this wharf 27 Jan - 6 Feb 1904.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: But infuriatingly, this date does not quite fit with the Sydney Mail article published on 27/1/1904...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] If that's the P&O wharf, then there's a good chance it's either RMS Moldavia or RMS India (which appears to have been at East Circular Quay from 8/1/1904 until its departure on 23/1/1904) - recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/PhotoSearchItemDetail.asp.... Looking at the pics I think the Moldavia is a better match, though it's difficult to be certain given the way ships were modified from time to time. I had hoped the ship we see at West Circular Quay in one of the companion pics might help narrow the date range...but it appears to be the NDL line mail steamer the Zieten...which arrived in Sydney on 17/1/1904 and departed on 30/1/1904...possibly moored at West Circular Quay for the duration of its stay...so it's no use! Of course neither the Moldavia nor the India appear to have had funnels like this ship...the very top sections appear to be of a narrower diameter than the rest...but maybe the funnels were modified at some point and so don't show up like this in any of the surviving pics...or maybe the top of the funnels included a telescopic section for some reason...or maybe I'm seeing things... As for the date issue...maybe the Sydney Mail was post dated? One other point...the SMH indicates that the Moldavia was moored at a buoy at Neutral Bay from the date of its arrival on 23/1/1904...I wonder why...particularly if the India departed on 23/1/1904...maybe another ship occupied the P&O wharf during the 2-3 day period until 27/1/1904.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It was the P&O wharf - see this wonderful 1905 birds-eye map (interactive) - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-f115-sd&rgn=-0... I discounted the INDIA because she looked like the CHINA with the mast behind the bridge in 1904 - www.simplonpc.co.uk/PO_Liners1.html#anchor217995 The MOLDAVIA funnels in silhouette - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71504965. This must have been taken when moored in Neutral Bay because of the publication date. I have her arriving on the 22nd (when the INDIA was still at the wharf), then "coaling" on the 25th, and as the flagship on the 26th. If it is not the MOLDAVIA at the wharf it has to be between 17-22 because the MOLDAVIA would show up moored in Neutral Bay. Infuriatingly complicated!!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hey aren't you on daylight saving? You'll turn into a pumpkin! The T&CJ pic is good for the funnels!...given your latest folio of evidence I'm now about 90+% convinced we're looking at the Moldavia...the India isn't a good match at all...plus as you say, if it were the India, we'd see the Moldavia at Neutral Bay. I gather there was at least one other ship with 2 funnels in Sydney at this time...the A&A line Sierra...but it's not a match...and it only appears to have been at East Circular Quay in the period 29/1/1904-1/2/1904...ie outside our date range. Hey the Sierra features on the interactive map!...and presumably it would have moored at the E&A wharf which we see in the map...it's not in the running here... It's a pity we see so little of the ship at the Burns Philp wharf in this pic www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363510276/

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I had hoped we might be able to get a few more clues re the date by comparing the various pics taken from the Dawes Point chimney...but as has been noted previously, it appears that some of the pics were taken at different times...maybe on the same day, or perhaps even on different days...and for all we know, by different photographers...which complicates things news.google.com/newspapers?id=8mxVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UpUDA... In this second lot of pics published in the Sydney Mail of 24/2/1904 it appears as if the Burns Philp wharf at East Circular Quay is vacant...but the ?Zieten still appears to be at its berth at West Circular Quay. The accompanying caption states: 'It happened, unfortunately, that at the moment the Japanese, American and Canadian liners were absent from their usual berths' ...the caption would have us believe that this second lot of Sydney Mail pics were taken on the same occasion as the pics that appeared in the issue of 27/1/1904 news.google.com/newspapers?id=7mxVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UpUDA... ... news.google.com/newspapers?id=72xVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UpUDA... this Sydney Mail pictorial item shows the Moldavia at the Anniversary Regatta...the pictorial is on the previous pages... Here's another pictorial item on the Moldavia news.google.com/newspapers?id=8GxVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UpUDA... I've now also realised that when viewed from a distance, ladders and pipes attached to the sides of a ship's funnel can sometimes appear to be part of the funnel and hence give the impression that the funnel has a narrower diameter top section. I suspect that's what I'm seeing here.
